It would have been impossible for any member 
of this small party to have stated the 'magnetic' bearing 
of an object without calculation whereas all were 
striving to keep their footsteps in a 'true' direction. 
To me and I believe other members of the 
Expedition the fact that the winds were recorded 'true' 
by all extended  sledge parties is so evident that it is 
no surprise to find the absence of a special entry 
confirming it. 
In quoting from a letter written by Lieutenant 
Royds nearly three years after the return of the 
Expedition Dr Shaw fails to give the context or to explain 
that the writer had not had access to the records when writing. 
Mr Royds informs me that the doubt he expressed 
had reference to certain short journeys made very soon 
after our arrival in McMurdo Sound. But even allowing 
for its more general application the passage quoted gives 
a renewed assurance that on the particular journey in 
question the winds were certainly recorded 'true'. 
In view of such overwhelming evidence how is 
it possible that Dr Shaw should conclude that the 
"first crucial test" had failed because of a doubt as to
